The Divide

  • Between tech and non-tech
  • Frustrations on both sides

Why me?

Well, I have an interesting history in the tech world...
  • I was this guy! There's a reason there aren't many pictures remaining of me from high school
  • Discovered computer games at age 8
  • Family wasn't technical, always encouraging me to spend less time on the computer (guilt complex!)
  • Called a geek or brain in school
  • Started working at HP doing web dev in High school
  • Computer Science at CalPoly
  • During my time at Microsoft, I got a little more "business-y"
  • And that caused resentment from the tech folks - called "overhead"

The challenge

  • Technology came naturally to me, people didn't
  • I explicitly took the challenge, going from dev to business as I joined Microsoft
  • Called abrasive... at Microsoft!
  • People are harder to deal with than the code!

Three C's of Communication

  • First, let's talk about the basic building blocks of dealing with humans

Clarity

  • Define terms
  • Summarize with paraphrasing
  • Agree on specific next steps
  • Send meeting notes
  • Define terms
    • story: Everett at Microsoft, early on
  • Summarize with paraphrasing
    • Exercise: have someone volunteer to paraphrase, have it be wrong. words are tricky!
    • I need this by Friday
    • This is extremely urgent! Get it to me ASAP.
    • Please have this on my desk by EOD today.
    • Please send the email in a few days.
  • Agree on specific next steps
  • Send meeting notes
    • at Microsoft I used to take notes on the screen - real-time summary paraphrase!

Confidence

  • Posture
  • Eye contact
  • No trail-off
  • Minimize weasel-words
  • Posture
    • the classic tech posture
    • [have everyone stand, shoulders back, chest forward, pelvis tilted a little back]
    • standing desk, multiple keyboards!
    • could do an entire talk on this
    • go to massage therapist, physical therapist
  • Eye contact
  • No trail-off
  • Minimize weasel-words
    • used to crack down on this as a Project Manager at Microsoft
    • speak plainly, no more and no less than necessary

A word on weasel words

  • Remove authority with passive voice: "it is said"
  • Weaken core idea: "often", "probably"
  • Remove specific numbers: "some people", "experts", "many"
More info: Wikipedia / weaselwords.com.au

Caring

  • Facial expressions, tones of voice
  • Be less judgmental!
  • Don't preach; influence
  • The Platinum Rule
  • [here is where we have the risk of looking evil]
  • Facial expressions, tones of voice
    • Beyond simple expressions, need to give them what they want, not what you want
    • The key is that the same action without that caring, the positive body language, can be interpreted poorly
  • Be less judgmental!
    • You know you do it - you're sure you're right, how could they possibly think so wrongly?
    • we're really bad actors
    • the best way to act like you care about someone is to actually care about them
    • maybe you're already considered evil? maybe have a history of negative interactions
    • will take time to break through
  • Don't preach; influence
    • Can't appeal to some random authority
    • Need to influence by speaking their language, connect to their priorities
  • The Platinum Rule
    • A step better than the golden rule
    • But it's even harder to do!
    • Story: Asked for two-page stories for christmas because I already had too much stuff.
    • I only got one story and a bunch of gifts.

    • A word on relationships

    • Acknowledge feelings
    • Contradict facts softly
    • Acknowledge feelings
    • Contradict facts softly
    • [the point is that we're valuing their perspective, even if it's different]

    First, Seek Understanding

    Pay attention!

    • build subconscious pattern recognition

      • Be deliberate in tuning your intuition!

      • [which was was better, higher quality?]
      • tuning your intuition - requires lots of data an experiences
      • switch companies/teams?
      • the more cultures, people and teams you work with, the more data, better the tuning

      Build and Test Mental Models

      • What do they know?
      • What mindset might cause their current behavior?
      • What are they trying to achieve with X action? Generally?
      • Consider larger context: incentives, deadlines, manager's desires, team, history, etc...
      • Test your theories by asking questions
      • [Now we start building on top of that subconcsious pattern recognition - verbalize!]
      • What do they know?
      • What mindset might cause their current behavior?
      • What are they trying to achieve with X action? Generally?
      • Consider larger context: incentives, deadlines, manager's desires, team, history, etc...
        • [exercise? hold two conflicting ideas in your head]
        • Key: you need to be okay with a different perspective
      • Test your theories by asking questions

      Getting Deeper

      Better questions

      • First, build trust
      • Important to do this 1 on 1
      • Open-ended, minimal leading
      • Ask why
      • "Tell me about the last time you X" (specific, recent)
      • Clarity: paraphrase, define words
      • How do they spend their time? money?
      • Try with your manager, peers, customers, friends, etc.
        • First, build trust
          • Again, with the evil - your percieved intentions matter here
        • Important to do this 1 on 1
          • People will affect each other's answers
        • Open-ended, minimal leading
          • you're trying to understand them, not influence them
          • trying to understand deeper attitudes, true priorities - how they think
        • Ask why or how questions
        • "Tell me about the last time you X" (specific, recent)
          • Breakin g through person's ideals about themselves
          • Most people have lofty ideals, noble pursuits.
          • when you look at how much time they actually spend on that stuff, it's pretty minimal
          • You can trace back the majority of their time to a few things: money, sex, power, food, physical comfort.
          • Now I'm starting to sound like a supervillain, justifying my plan to kill of most of the human race.
          • That's the crazy thing. This is humanity, and it applies to all of us too.
        • Clarity: paraphrase, define words
        • How do they spend their time? money?
        • Try with your manager, peers, customers, friends, etc.
          • From Steve Blank's Customer Development

      A word on evil

      • Easy to 'fall into'
      • Fairness matters
      • Do they have any other options?
      • Is it too direct?
      • Did you give them a chance to help?
        • Easy to 'fall into'
          • The real world isn't superheroes and supervillains.
          • Free-to-play games - is that abusing deep knowledge of psychology?
        • Fairness matters
          • You're collaborating on something. Make sure the outcome is reasonably fair for you.
          • Be sure to give credit to those your worked with.
        • Do they have any other options?
          • Uber's congestion pricing
          • High-priced umbrellas (rain) or fans and AC (heat)
          • People taking low-wage jobs
        • Is it too direct?
          • Need to make sure to address higher ideas as well as low-level needs/desires
          • Money and meaning makes for a better, fuller job
          • Straight porn vs. using sex to sell in a subtle way
        • Did you give them a chance to help?
          • It's a hit to pride if you just do something for someone

      Summary

      • Become a student of human behavior
      • First, seek understanding
        • Pay attention: tune intuition with lots of data
        • Build and test mental models
        • Get deeper: past the abstract and ideal
      • Communicate well - three C's
        • Clarity
        • Confidence
        • Caring: the platinum rule, judge less
      • Solve problems!
